newsitem.title: USA: Diet drugs may cause heart damage - Mayo Clinic.
newsitem.headline: Diet drugs may cause heart damage - Mayo Clinic.

text.p: A popular combination of weight-loss medications may have caused heart problems in relatively young women, Mayo Clinic researchers said Tuesday.

The diet drugs fenfluramine and phentermine, prescribed to 18 million people last year in a combination commonly called "fen-phen," may have been responsible for a thickening of the heart valves in 24 women.
A report on the finding will be published next month in the New England Journal of Medicine, which agreed to allow the information to be disseminated early, the Mayo Clinic said.
"We began to notice that otherwise healthy young women, presenting with this unusual form of valve disease, were also on fen-phen," cardiologist Heidi Connolly said in a statement.
On routine doctor visits, the women were found to have cardiovascular symptoms or heart murmurs after having taken the weight-loss medications for an average of one year.

"We don't know how fen-phen may cause injury to the heart valves," Connolly said. "We do know that fenfluramine and phentermine alter the way the brain chemical serotonin is metabolised, and serotonin that circulates in the blood can cause (heart) valve injury."
The valve damage caused blood to leak back into the heart, making it work harder, she said.
Previous research has indicated the weight-loss medications can raise blood pressure in arteries between the heart and the lungs in some patients.
